AEM13920 Portal
Getting Started

This page provides a quick start guide for the AEM13920 HAL driver, covering topics from initialization to reading internal data. It complements the Libraries section, which offers a detailed API reference.

Prerequisites

Dependencies

To integrate this driver into a project, include the HAL_AEM13920.h file in the main project file. Ensure the following libraries are available in the project environment:

  • HAL_AEM13920.c & HAL_AEM13920.h
  • AEM13920_RegisterMap.h & AEM13920_Common.h
  • AEM_I2C.h

These files are included in the software package available on the Downloads page.

Communication Interface

As described in the I2C Communication interface section, the four functions specified in the AEM_I2C.h header file must also be implemented in your project for communication.

Status/Error codes

All the functions return a Status/Error code, that indicate the kind of error that occurred.

Initialization sequence

Reset Sequence

Before using the driver, ensure the AEM has completed its reset sequence and is ready to communicate. The IRQ pin can be monitored for this purpose, as described in the datasheet.

Data structures and I2C interface

All functions in this driver take a pointer to a variable of type AEM13920_Handler_t, which is required versioning and to the communication interface aspects.

TThe AEM13920_Handler_t structure consists of two fields: one for the chip's revision and the other for a pointer to an AEM_i2c_cfg structure, which is necessary for I2C communication. The details of this structure and its usage are described in the I2C Communication interface section of this documentation.

Initialization

After correctly configuring the I2C interface, call AEM13920_Initialize() to initialize the interface. The driver will then be ready for use.

Below is the typical initialization sequence:

// Optional callback function
void aem_callback(int32_t event)
{
// User's code
}
// Initialize the I2C interface data structure
AEM_i2c_cfg aem_comm_iface;
aem_comm_iface.usr_callback = aem_callback; // Set to NULL to disable
aem_comm_iface.interface = 0; // Depends on the implementation
aem_comm_iface.slaveAddress = 0x41; // See the datasheet for the slave address
// Initialize the AEM's handler structure
AEM13920_Handler_t aem_handler;
aem_handler.i2c_cfg = &aem_comm_iface;
// Call the driver initialization function
AEM13920_Initialize(&aem_handler);
AEM13920_Handler_t::i2c_cfg
AEM_i2c_cfg * i2c_cfg

Configuring the AEM

The driver provides two methods for configuring the AEM13920. One option is to use a data structure, which is passed to the AEM13920_SetConfiguration() function to set the entire configuration in a single operation. The other option is to use dedicated setters to configure specific elements individually. The choice between these two methods depends on the context. The following sections outline the advantages and disadvantages of each approach and how to implement them.

Set the whole configuration area

The AEM must be fully configured. In this case, a variable of type AEM13920_CONFIG_t must be declared and set according to the desired configuration. Passing this variable to the AEM13920_SetConfiguration() function will update the AEM behavior accordingly.

This approach reduces the overhead associated with the communication interface, as a single transfer will configure the entire I2C register area (bulk transfer) and trigger the synchronization of the system registers simultaneously.

AEM13920_CONFIG_t aem_cfg;
aem_cfg->temp_rdiv = 22000000; /* Fill in the correct value, in mOhms */
// Read the current configuration (i.e. reset values)
AEM13920_GetConfiguration(&aem_handler, &aem_cfg);
// Set the data structure with the required configuration settings
aem_cfg.src1_regu_mode = AEM13920_SRCREGU_CONST;
aem_cfg.src1_const_voltage = 600;
aem_cfg.src1_boost_tmult = AEM13920_TMULT2;
aem_cfg.src1_boost_enable = true;
aem_cfg.src1_boost_high_power_enable = true;
aem_cfg.src1_low_thresh = AEM13920_SRCLOW_THRESH_112;
aem_cfg.src2_regu_mode = AEM13920_SRCREGU_MPPT;
aem_cfg.src2_mppt_ratio = AEM13920_MPPT_RATIO_75;
aem_cfg.src2_mppt_duration = AEM13920_MPPT_DUR8;
aem_cfg.src2_mppt_period = AEM13920_MPPT_PER512;
aem_cfg.src2_boost_tmult = AEM13920_TMULT2;
aem_cfg.src2_boost_enable = true;
aem_cfg.src2_boost_high_power_enable = true;
aem_cfg.src2_low_thresh = AEM13920_SRCLOW_THRESH_112;
aem_cfg.vovdis = 2500;
aem_cfg.vchrdy = 2550;
aem_cfg.vovch = 3800;
aem_cfg.buck_vout = AEM13920_VOUT_2200;
aem_cfg.buck_tmult = AEM13920_TMULT4;
aem_cfg.temp_mon_enable = true;
aem_cfg.i2c_rdy_irq_enable = true;
// ...
// - Write the updated configuration to the I2C registers,
// - Start the synchronization of the registers,
// - Wait for it to complete
AEM13920_SetConfiguration(&aem_handler, &aem_cfg, true);

Only configure specific features

If only specific configuration elements need to be updated, the relevant SetXXX, EnableXXX, or DisableXXX functions can be called. This will ensure that only the necessary registers are written. Afterward, the AEM13920_SyncI2CConfiguration() function should be called to synchronize the system registers with the configuration set in the I2C registers.

These functions should be used sparingly, as each call triggers I2C write operations, and some may require read operations. Excessive usage can lead to significant increases in energy consumption.

Similarly, the synchronization function should be called only after updating as many configuration elements as possible, rather than after each individual setter call.

// Only enable APM on buck
AEM13920_EnableAPMBuck(&aem_handler);
// Update the AEM accordingly
AEM13920_SyncI2CConfiguration(&aem_handler);
AEM13920_EnableAPMBuck
int32_t AEM13920_EnableAPMBuck(const AEM13920_Handler_t *handler)
Enable the Average Power Monitoring for the buck converter.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:2204
AEM13920_SyncI2CConfiguration
int32_t AEM13920_SyncI2CConfiguration(const AEM13920_Handler_t *handler, bool blocking)
Load the I2C configuration.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:3083
Note
For most configuration registers, the API offers two options: a function to configure the entire register using a data structure, and separate functions to configure each field individually. To optimize energy efficiency, it is recommended to use the first option whenever possible. The individual field functions are mainly provided for user convenience, rather than for efficiency.

Reading the configuration of the AEM

Warning
Note that when using this driver's functions to read the AEM's configuration, the functions return the configuration set in the I2C registers. If changes are made using the AEM13920_SetXXX, AEM13920_EnableXXX, or AEM13920_DisableXXX functions without a subsequent call to AEM13920_SyncI2CConfiguration(), the values returned by the AEM13920_GetXXX functions will not reflect the actual configuration of the AEM.

As for writing the configuration, there are two ways of reading the configuration of the AEM, each with its own advantages and disadvantages.

Read the whole configuration area

When a series of configuration settings need to be retrieved, the most efficient option is to read all the configuration area in a single transaction (bulk transfer), and then query the specific settings. This can be done by calling the AEM13920_GetConfiguration() function, that populates the user's data structure from the AEM configuration.

AEM13920_Config aem_cfg;
aem_cfg->temp_rdiv = 22000000; /* Fill in the correct value, in mOhms, so that the
temperature thresholds can be computed */
AEM13920_GetConfiguration(&aem_handler, &aem_cfg);
if (aem_cfg.apm_buck_enable) {
// ...
}
AEM13920_CONFIG_t::apm_buck_enable
bool apm_buck_enable
Enable/Disable the Average Power Monitoring for the buck.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.h:148

Only read specific elements of configuration

When only a few number of settings need to be checked, the GetXXX and IsEnabledXXX functions can be used. This way, only the relevant registers are read to retrieve the required information.

bool apm_buck_enable = false;
AEM13920_IsEnabledAPMBuck(&aem_handler, &apm_buck_enable);
if (apm_buck_enable) {
// ...
}
AEM13920_IsEnabledAPMBuck
int32_t AEM13920_IsEnabledAPMBuck(const AEM13920_Handler_t *handler, bool *en)
Get the enabling status of the Average Power Monitoring for the buck converter.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:2236
Note
For most configuration registers, the API offers two options: a function to read the entire register and populate a data structure accordingly, and separate functions to read each field individually. To optimize energy efficiency, it is recommended to use the first option whenever possible. The individual field functions are mainly provided for user convenience, rather than for efficiency.

Reading the AEM status

The AEM's status can be retrieved using the AEM13920_GetStatus() function:

AEM13920_STATUS_t status;
AEM13920_GetStatus(&aem_handler, &status);
if (status.vovdis) {
// ...
}
AEM13920_STATUS_t::vovdis
bool vovdis
Overdischarge status.
Definition: AEM13920_Common.h:671
AEM13920_STATUS_t
Status.
Definition: AEM13920_Common.h:665
AEM13920_GetStatus
int32_t AEM13920_GetStatus(const AEM13920_Handler_t *handler, AEM13920_STATUS_t *status)
Get the AEM's status.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:3378

Individual field functions are provided for convenience, but should be used sparingly, as each field function triggers an I2C transaction:

  • AEM13920_GetOverdischargeStatus()
  • AEM13920_GetChargeReadyStatus()
  • AEM13920_GetOverchargeStatus()
  • AEM13920_GetSRCLowStatus()
  • AEM13920_GetTempHotChargeStatus()
  • AEM13920_GetTempHotDischargeStatus()
  • AEM13920_GetTempColdChargeStatus()
  • AEM13920_GetTempColdDischargeStatus()

Reading the AEM IRQ flags

When using the AEM's IRQ pin, it is necessary to determine which interrupt was triggered when entering the dedicated interrupt service routine. This information can be retrieved by calling the AEM13920_GetIRQFlags() function:

AEM13920_IRQFLG_t flags;
AEM13920_GetIRQFlags(&aem_handler, &flags);
if (flags.vovdis) {
// ...
}
AEM13920_IRQFLG_t::vovdis
bool vovdis
Overdischarge flag.

Individual field functions are provided for convenience, but should be used sparingly, as each field function triggers an I2C transaction:

  • AEM13920_GetI2CReadyFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetOverdischargeFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetChargeReadyFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetOverchargeFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetSRCLowFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetTempChargeFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetTempDischargeFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetMPPTStartFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetMPPTDoneFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetSTODoneFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetTempDoneFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetAPMDoneFlag()
  • AEM13920_GetAPMErrFlag()

Reading the AEM's data

Various functions can be used to retrieve the AEM's generated data:

  • AEM13920_GetAPMSourceData(),
  • AEM13920_GetAPMBuckData(),
  • AEM13920_GetAPMErrors(),
  • AEM13920_GetThermistorZ(),
  • AEM13920_GetSourceRegulationVoltage(), and
  • AEM13920_GetStorageVoltage()

Individual field functions are also provided for convenience, but should be used sparingly, as each field function triggers an I2C transaction:

  • AEM13920_IsAPMSourceOverflow(),
  • AEM13920_IsAPMSourceCorrupted(),
  • AEM13920_IsAPMBuckOverflow(),
  • AEM13920_IsAPMBuckCorrupted(),
